work_equality: To be exact, after my return to Germany. I gave a long answer before.
label: family_planning/undermining
work_unsupported: Wheras men are supportet and invited, for example to publish with the boss and getting great recommendation letters for applying to professorships my female colleagues and I are doing the ground work, teaching for example but that doesn' count it is expected of women that they pick up the slack that some men don't like to do. The old buddy network is well alive and younger cohorts of male scientists are socialized into the old paradigm.
work_collaborations: Irefered to it in my comment before.
work_infrastructure: Women still don't ask enough and are constantly afraid that someone could be angry with them or not liking them because that's what they learned and what men still expect of women. I don't follow those ruels and because I make known what I can and what I want I get the label of being aggressive. I don't really care I am old enough to handle it and I have enough experience but my younger colleagues don't. I also see the issues of men though. They don't ask for family leave or only the two months because it's still not acknowledge that many times a child has two parents.
technical_publications: Oh yes, and it's even worth with grant applications. Grant applications are written by the colleagues but on the cover sheet are only mentioned the names of the PIs who already have a professorship. I really hate that doing the work but getting no credit for it!!! At my institution it is an unwritten rule that regardless of input and work at an article the directors always mentioned at last. It just sucks and as long as the BMBF or DFG don't change the rules regarding cover sheets on grant applications and more stern regrding authorship nothing will change.
technical_researcher: Constantly, also explained in more detail before.

birth_country: eastern part of the EU (not in Germany)

work_collaborations: Being talked over and ignored, having less published output because male colleagues tend to care less about how good their output is
technical_appreciation: more visible, get invited to debates etc.
technical_others: Most male colleagues are so much better at asking for stuff, being loud and getting heard

work_unsupported_solution: I looked for new contexts of exchange relationships on an informal base

i have a child and companies afraid of me if i would have my second one.
no Companies accept me if i am pregnit
i can not work in shift work because of my family
i have no experience in working
the companies want someone speaking German fluently
work_equality: the german are alloways choosen by companies
label: Ininternationality
work_unsupported: Men allways have the priority to travel foe working, seminars or conferences
technical_ideasharing: many conferences where i can share my ideasare not allowd for me

work_equality:
I was lucky not to have faced serious discrimination, just a few anekdotes. During my studies a collegue answered to all of my question with "And you dont know this?" And then explained things. It took me some semesters to realize that he had not the slightest clue im most of the times and was just talking nonsense. He did not behave the same way to our male collegues. 
Lately (Im at the very end of my phd) I sometimes here the comment (when talking about becoming professors) that I have high chances to become one because Im a woman. Not because im skilled or eager. Just because women are prefered in generell. (Which is depatable in my opinion having under 10% female professors in my field in Germany). I also participate in a networking programm for female scientists and very often my male collegues and my professor feel discriminated because they are not allowed to take part in it (not to say that similar courses are offered by the gradschool for all genders which the very same collegues never participate in).
label: Undermining
work_equality_solution: Well, just have the facts at hand and tell them that their opinion is not reflecting the reality and that man still dont suffer generic discrimination in the hard sciences.

cultural_others_description: bearing and caring for my children
work_equality:
Male colleagues were more often praised and encouraged, even when they were not as productive and did not take as much responsility as i did.
It was rather depressing when i was more often at work and actually got more work done as a part time worker, than my male colleague with full time (and full pay!) and still, he got praised, while i was ignored.
label: Salary_Expectation
work_unsupported: Having kids and supporting women was a big thing, until it really happened. Then it was a nuissance at work.
technical_publications_solution: I had to wait 4 years to publish my work.  - but i did in the end, because i did not give up.

work_equality: Non-research tasks at work (at the institute) are often applied to women, because it is assumed that women do better in the, e.g., included organizational aspects of non-research work (which is possibly true, but leads to situations, where women very often do big parts of the non-research stuff, while men can focus on their own research).
label: Undermining

work_collaborations: With some men, esp. in my own lab, I find it sometimes hard to collaborate since their style of communication appears to be rather egocentric than collaborative.
work_collaborations_solution: I adapated some sort of communication of being more straight forward, strincter and communicating my needs directly but friendly.
technical_appreciation: Some male researchers I met are just more confident in "selling" their work and thus get more appreciation, whereas I recognized in myself (but also some other female researchers) we are more critical about our own work.
technical_appreciation_solution: I don't get "bedazzled" by some bragging anymore and try to be more appreciative of my successes and my hard work .

technical_publications: Yes, many times. I think every researcher does so.

work_collaborations: Adoption of results which I was the PI for.

technical_researcher: No concrete situation. Just sometimes had the impression that results or presentations by female researchers were questioned more strongly than that of male researchers.
technical_researcher_solution: Trying to paint too much attention to it

cultural_others_description: None,  I did not face any cultural problems
technical_ideasharing: This is dependent to th sturcture of my PhD. A (male) colleaque at my institute has the same problem.

work_collaborations: Some men have been sexist or did not see their priviledges

work_equality: different expectation for men and women
label: Meet_expectations

cultural_clothing_description: Clothing conventions make you feel comfortable in a group. Coming from a girl's school, it took me some time to realizem, that clothing did not matter at all in my physics studies. Nor in negative nor in positive ways: self-tailored nice garment was not even noticed. After short disappointment I learnt to appreciate that freedom. Switching to engineering changed the situation entirely: suddenly formal clothes were required at least during exams. The first fees as a young scientists I spent on buying white blouses. The first years at congresses and business meetings, the male attendees seemed to dress quite uniformly. As one of the few women at these events I searched for role models "what to wear". Most of the few female material scientists did not wear typical business attire, but practical and very individual stiles. That enouraged me to dress in my own colors, in my own preferred stile: My difficulties were self-made. Being one of the few women made me free of conventions.
cultural_clothing_solution_description: see above: Decision not to follow conventions
cultural_infrastructure_description: Some equipment in labs is not designed for short people
cultural_infrastructure_solution_descrip: Ask for help, buy a footstool, assemble a diverse group of people
work_infrastructure: see above: Equimpent with too high windows, handles,...
work_infrastructure_solution: see above: Footstool, help, diverse group
technical_others: Womens achievements are not visible if only initials are qouted
technical_others_solution: Giving whole names, wherever it is possible. In public talks, I emphasize womens achievements as examples for successful results.

cultural_others_description: To understand the sctandard and tradition of how to research in Germany. It is quite a challange how to be able to communicate with German collagues and prof. appropriately since there are so many cultural differences. E.g.: My Prof. think thy when I write an email,... I  did not go directly to the point. Meanwhile, in my culture, it is  unpolite to be so direct.
cultural_others_solution_description: I explain the cultural dimension in my country, we discuss and I try to follow  the German culture and be direct. Menahwile, my prof also try to understand  the way I comunicate and structure my thought within the framework of my cultural background.
work_others: Short term working contract at the university is stressfull (no clear perspective)
technical_ideasharing: Everybody are bussy and my profs supervised many doctoral students. So he hast to share his resources.

cultural_clothing_description: It is a kind of informal norm to wear trouser and pant. No one in my company ever wear their traditional cloth not even one day.
cultural_namechanging_description: I have no surname. I always have difficulty to explain this. Single name is not enough to identify a person in Germany.
work_unsupported: It is really hard to get a research paper and guidance in particular topic. If research paper is free then you can download it but if not then leave it. Same applies of Norms..
work_unsupported_solution:
Whenever I need a norms I just write email to everyone asking for it. If someone have it I get it. 
For research paper there is no solution. Even finding books is also tough. 
There is a rocket chat now by which we can ask specific question to the group.

work_others: During my pregancy I was not sure, if I could go into all laboratories or if there were dangerous materials stored or had been used inside

cultural_infrastructure_solution_descrip: Constant communication about who I am, being the person that run under a different name before.
work_infrastructure: lack of information on how to establish internatonal cooperation, short term stay aborad with small children
work_others:
corona: work from home is the insitutional agenda, however postal messages and forms are not forwarded. 
difficulty when onboarding that the new university and research institute: mobile onboarding covers administration but not and "explanation" about administrative ways and organizational culture.
technical_ideasharing: difficulty to attend conferences when parenting

technical_appreciation: Yes, as they seem more intelligent and competent.
technical_appreciation_solution: Show that every one should be rated according to his/her qualification.

Ich hatte den Eindruck, dass meine haupts�chlich mannlichen Kollegen �berkritische Fragen stellten, die zudem erkennen lie�en, dass sie dem Vortrag nur teilweise gefolgt waren. Ein Kollege merkte danach an, ich h�tte wie eine Grundschullehrerin gewirkt. cultural_namechanging_description: Ich habe bei der Hochzeit meinen Namen nicht ge�ndert, weil ich Angst hatte, dass man meine Ver�ffentlichungen dann nicht mehr auf meine Autorinnenschaft beziehen kann. Das habe ich nachtr�glich ein wenig bereut.
work_collaborations: In der Zusammenarbeit mit M�nners herrscht eine deutlich agressiver Umganston. Das schreckt mich oft ab, mit ihnen zusammenarbeiten zu wollen.

cultural_clothing_description:
In Spain and Italy clothing being a woman can be misunderstood. In certain circles it is stressful to decide what to wear to not be judge from others. This can make you feel uncomfortable and insecure in your work. 
In India, basically you have to adapt to their cultural rules even if you don't agree. 
In Germany this aspect has been easier than in other countries. I had felt more freedom.
cultural_infrastructure_description: Faculties of architecture are changing a lot in the last years in terms of women presence. In the past it was fundamentally a men career, now it is the opposite. In that sense, normally, the University is not adapted to certain needs we have: security in the night, good toilets infrastructure, flexibility for mothers and future mothers.
cultural_infrastructure_solution_descrip:
Adapting to what is there
Discussing the problem with others
Proposing ideas 
Complaining in certain situations
cultural_others_description: Communication: In one hand because language itself is sometimes men chauvinist.  Then because men always speak more in public events and are less inclusive than women.
work_unsupported: Still we are afraid to address certain topics in a bottom up process. We need a topdown compromise. Culture is behind in that aspect.
work_collaborations: I had fantastic and horrible experiences both with women and men but I would like to highlight that as architecture and planning in the precedent generation of mine was mainly a men discipline, sometimes I feel in minority in certain activities. From this minority is more difficult to empower.
technical_appreciation: Sometimes this happens but for the issue I mentioned before of being in minority.
technical_others: If you see architectural couples working together, normally the men is a PhD and the woman no. Research needs time and concentration and it is difficult the conciliation with family.

cultural_namechanging_description: Name translation and adaptation to another language
work_unsupported: Not so much promotion for the foreign scientists
technical_publications: It was hierarchical issue, not because of gender.

scientific_field: I am just taking a look at the questionnaire
